Expectation1: Take and record vital signs like temperature, pulse, and blood pressure
Situation1: A patient is recovering from a recent procedure and has slightly elevated vital signs.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I stood in the hospital room, clipboard in hand, watching the numbers on the monitor. The patient’s temperature was a little high, pulse a bit fast—nothing alarming, but I knew I had to record every detail and report any changes. My supervisor expected accuracy and vigilance; the patient’s recovery depended on it. My stomach rumbled, reminding me I hadn’t eaten since early morning. Down the hall, the staff lounge buzzed with laughter from the communal lunch. I peeked in and saw trays of food, but none bore the kosher certification I needed. I felt the familiar ache of hunger and isolation. My colleagues expected me to join, to be part of the team, but I couldn’t compromise my beliefs. I glanced at the patient’s chart, then at the food, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in. I wanted to do right by my patient and my faith, but the demands seemed to pull me in opposite directions. My hands trembled as I tried to focus on the numbers, my mind torn between duty and devotion, unsure which expectation I could meet without letting the other down.
